The discography of American singer Bryson Tiller consists of three studio albums, one mixtape, one extended play, 23 singles and 12 music videos. He started his career in 2011, releasing the mixtape *Killer Instinct Vol.1*.[1] In October 2015, Tiller released his debut studio album, *Trapsoul*, which reached number eight on the US *Billboard* 200.[2] Two of the album's singles, "Don't" and "Exchange", have peaked in the top 40 of the US *Billboard* Hot 100.[3] Tiller's second studio album, *True to Self*, was released on May 26, 2017, and peaked at number one on the US *Billboard* 200, becoming his first number-one album in the country.[4]

Months later, on December 18, he announced the release of the lead single of *Breezy* for January 2022.[32] On the first day of 2022 he announced the title of the single, "Iffy", through a teaser of its music video, announcing its release for January 14, while also revealing that *Breezy* would have the same amount of songs of his debut album, because he wanted to "keep it classic".[33] In March he announced that the already previewed song "Warm Embrace" would be the second single, announcing its release date for April 1, and teasing a joint tour for Summer 2022 with a mystery co-headliner.[34] Two days before the release of the single, he revealed that *Breezy* would be released during summer 2022.[35] In late April he announced his "One of Them Ones Tour" with rapper Lil Baby as a co-headlining act.[36] On May 9 he announced that the album would be released in June.[37] Nine days later he revealed *Breezy*'s release date, June 24, along with its cover art, and a list of features including Lil Wayne, Blxst,

*Breezy'*s opener is the hip hop track "Till the Wheels Fall Off", featuring Lil Durk and Capella Grey, that runs for 5 minutes and 14 seconds, having a chorus that Brown executes singing with a bass voice and "intense" harmonies.[21] Lyrically, on the song the artists give a hopeful introspection over their emotional struggles caused by their personal life's harshest challenges.[22] The second track "Catch a Body", featuring Fivio Foreign, mixes R&B and drill music, containing swaggering lyrics.[21] The following track, "Pitch Black", is an R&B mid-tempo with sexual themes, with an intro performed by Anderson .Paak.[21] On "Possessive" Yung Bleu, Lil Wayne and Brown explore themes of jealousy, breakup and lovesickness, through a tone that was described by Miracle Oyedeji of *The Inquirer* as a "mixture of loving and nagging".[21] "Need You Right Here", "Hmhmm", and "Addicted" are trap-influenced R&B tracks with debaucherous themes.[21] "Survive the Night" is an alternative R&B track about drug addiction,

<fragment>

***Breezy*** is the tenth studio album by American singer Chris Brown, released on June 24, 2022, as the follow-up to his 2019 album *Indigo*.[6] The artists featured on the album are Lil Wayne, Anderson .Paak, Blxst, Lil Baby, H.E.R., EST Gee, Wizkid, Jack Harlow, Tory Lanez, Fivio Foreign, Ella Mai, Yung Bleu, Capella Grey, Lil Durk, Davido and Bryson Tiller. The album marks his first studio album not being a double-disc since his 2015 album *Royalty*.


*Breezy* is an R&B album, also containing trap-driven and soul songs. Its lyrical content mostly mixes themes of romance and sex. The album debuted at number four on the US *Billboard* 200, making it his lowest charting album in that country since *Graffiti* (2009). *Breezy* was preceded by three singles; "Iffy", "WE (Warm Embrace)" and "Call Me Every Day". At the 65th Grammy Awards, the deluxe edition of *Breezy* was nominated for Best R&B Album.[7]

On December 22, 2019, Brown announced that he was working on new material for his next album, posting an Instagram story where he wrote "2020, what do you think my 10th album is going to be called?".[25] A couple months following the release of his collaborative mixtape with Young Thug, *Slime & B*, on July 9, 2020, he announced that the name of his tenth album would be *Breezy*, making a reference to his stage nickname.[26] On October 22, 2020 he shared through his social media a snippet of a song supposedly called "On Some New Shit", in a video that showed him working and recording the song in a hotel room in London, also suggesting the possibility of releasing the album in 2021 in the video's caption.[27] In November, Brown created an OnlyFans account, where he posted snippets from the songs "Sleep at Night" and "Warm Embarce", during his travel in Tulum, Mexico.[28] Two days before Christmas 2020, Brown posted on his Instagram account a picture that showed a pen and a piece of paper,

Miracle Oyedeji of *The Inquirer* stated that the album consists of "24 solid songs" with Brown doing "amazingly well vocally and lyrically".[21] AllMusic editor Andy Kellman praised *Breezy'*s "soulful" side, stating that it "contains some of the smoothest R&B he has made", but was dissatisfied with its "boastful" hip hop-infused side.[24] Lauren Floyd of *HipHopDX* expressed a mixed response, stating that on the album "certain songs sway from trend to trend or the preferences of its features mask more than advertising Brown's individuality".[3]



## Release and promotion[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
captioning it with "My heart on this pen and pad. A SIDE B SIDE. Hope y'all f\*\*k with my frequency. No time soon", hinting the possibility of *Breezy* being his third consecutive double-album, following *Heartbreak on a Full Moon* and *Indigo*.[29] On January 8, 2021 *Forbes* published an article that listed *Breezy* among the most anticipated R&B albums of 2021.[30] In June 2021 he said that he was not in a rush to release his new album, by posting an Instagram story where he wrote "I ain't dropping my album until I'm ready. I need to give y'all a chance to miss me".[31]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Chris Brown started working on the album simultaneously with the release of his ninth studio album *Indigo*.[8] The singer said in July 2021, while working on the album, that he wanted to make some "really endearing music" that "talk to women's soul".[9] In February 2022, he stated on his Instagram account that the album would contain some pure R&B material.[10] He later said that on some of the album's songs he wanted to depict "a different type of love mixed with heartbreak".[11] The recording sessions for *Breezy* ended during the first days of June 2022. During the album's work, the singer stated that he recorded almost 250 songs.[12][13] During an interview with Big Boy, one week before *Breezy'*s release, the singer said that the project is more targeted towards his female audience.[8]



## Artwork[edit]


</fragment>

H.E.R., Ella Mai, Jack Harlow, Tory Lanez, Fivio Foreign, Yung Bleu, EST Gee and Wizkid, hinting that more features could be on the album.[38]


Brown unveiled the album's track listing on June 7, while also posting a video of him dancing to a snippet of "Possessive".[39] Two weeks before the album's release, Brown has debuted the track "Wheels Fall Off", performing the track for the first time for the "4ShootersOnly" music platform, in a video portraying himself alone with a microphone in his backyard, while he smokes a blunt and executes the song.[40] That same day he posted a snippet of "Call Me Every Day", featuring Nigerian artist WizKid, on his Instagram account.[41] On June 21, he released the music video for "WE (Warm Embrace)", starring Normani and directed by Arrad.[42]

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
### Breezy (Album)

**Breezy** is the tenth studio album by American singer Chris Brown, released on June 24, 2022, as the follow-up to his 2019 album *Indigo*. The album features a variety of artists including Lil Wayne, Anderson .Paak, Blxst, Lil Baby, H.E.R., EST Gee, Wizkid, Jack Harlow, Tory Lanez, Fivio Foreign, Ella Mai, Yung Bleu, Capella Grey, Lil Durk, Davido, and Bryson Tiller. Notably, this album marks his first studio album not being a double-disc since his 2015 album *Royalty*.

**Musical Style and Themes:**
*Breezy* is primarily an R&B album, also containing trap-driven and soul songs. The lyrical content mostly revolves around themes of romance and sex. The album debuted at number four on the US *Billboard* 200, making it his lowest charting album in the country since *Graffiti* (2009). The album was preceded by three singles: "Iffy", "WE (Warm Embrace)", and "Call Me Every Day". At the 65th Grammy Awards, the deluxe edition of *Breezy* was nominated for Best R&B Album.

**Track Listing:**
1. "Till the Wheels Fall Off" (featuring Lil Durk and Capella Grey)
2. "C.A.B. (Catch a Body)" (featuring Fivio Foreign)
3. "Pitch Black"
4. "Possessive" (featuring Lil Wayne and Yung Bleu)
5. "Addicted" (featuring Lil Baby)
6. "Call Me Every Day" (featuring Wizkid)
7. "Closure" (featuring H.E.R.)
8. "Need You Right Here" (featuring Bryson Tiller)
9. "Sex Memories" (featuring Ella Mai)
10. "Hmhmm" (featuring EST Gee)
11. "Psychic" (featuring Jack Harlow)
12. "Show It" (featuring Blxst)
13. "Sleep at Night"
14. "Passing Time"
15. "WE (Warm Embrace)"
16. "Forbidden"
17. "Bad Then a Beach" (featuring Tory Lanez)
18. "Survive the Night"
19. "Dream"
20. "Slide"
21. "Harder"
22. "On Some New Shit"
23. "Luckiest Man"
24. "Iffy" (Bonus Track)

**Reception:**
The album received mixed reviews. Miracle Oyedeji of *The Inquirer* praised the album for its solid songs and Brown's vocal and lyrical performance. AllMusic editor Andy Kellman appreciated the album's soulful side but was less impressed with its boastful hip hop-infused tracks. Lauren Floyd of *HipHopDX* had a mixed response, noting that some songs seemed to follow trends rather than showcasing Brown's individuality.

**Background and Recording:**
Chris Brown began working on *Breezy* simultaneously with the release of his ninth studio album *Indigo*. He aimed to create endearing music that speaks to women's souls. The recording sessions for *Breezy* ended in early June 2022, with Brown stating that he recorded almost 250 songs for the album. The project is more targeted towards his female audience, with themes of love and heartbreak.

**Promotion:**
Brown announced the album's title in July 2020 and shared snippets of songs through social media and his OnlyFans account. The album's track listing was unveiled on June 7, 2022, and Brown promoted the album by performing tracks and releasing music videos.

**Artwork:**
The album cover and promotional materials were shared through Brown's social media accounts, building anticipation for the release.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the full Wikipedia article on [Breezy (album)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breezy_(album)).
